Problem:
Consider a complex function \\(z(t) = x(t) + iy(t)\\), where \\(x(t)\\) and \\(y(t)\\) are real functions of time t, governed by the differential equations \\(\\dot{x} = Ax\\) and \\(\\dot{y} = By\\), and A and B are scalar constants. We explore causal relationships under the Fourier transform defined as \\(\\hat{z}(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-i\\omega t}z(t)\\, dt\\).

If an intervention is applied where a scaling function \\(s(t) = e^{Ct}\\) is multiplied to z(t) at a time t_1, will the new state \\(\\hat{z}(\\omega)\\) reflect only the impact of A and B or also C?
Explanation: The application of the scaling function \\(s(t) = e^{Ct}\\) affects the subsequent evolution of the function by introducing a new exponential factor, significantly altering the response characteristics captured in \\(\\hat{z}(\\omega)\\). Thus, the new transformation reflects A, B, and C.
